title: Which songs do you hate the lyrics (or message), but still love the song? - Quora

response.answer_text: This song was big, huge, the gorilla, the song that invented the term “gorilla” in reference to music hits. There were hits and popular songs, but when it came out, this was a phenomenon:  Rock and roll by its nature invokes raunch and rebellion. It’s supposed to be subversive and naughty and the answer to “What will we do on Saturday night?” After all, you can’t think of sex and drugs without adding rock and roll. The Knack came out of nowhere, and faster than you can say “state fair headliner,” they were gone. But they left behind an imprint that touched on every tenet of a good rock song: lust, longing, and sweet release. Propelled by that signature bass line alternating octaves and Doug Fieger’s leer translated into a howl of teen anguish, “My Sharona” demanded to know what every teenage boy with blue balls wanted to know: “When are we doing it?” This isn’t new to rock songs. This question had been asked in more subtle or clever ways in order to avoid angering the authorities-that-be. The fact that it begins by asking when the sex can start (“Ooh my little pretty one, pretty one/When you gonna give me some time Sharona?”) isn’t the issue. The imagery of having a dirty mind and running it “down the length of my thigh, Sharona” doesn’t cause any problems. But here I am, a grown-ass adult with kids of my own, and I can’t sing along with a great song from my youth when it gets to: “I always get it up for the touch of the younger kind.” Buzz. Killed. This didn’t bother me when I was younger; remember, rock and roll is for rebels. I wasn’t taking the lyrics to heart back then any more than I was paying attention to my parents when they told me to pick up my clothes off the floor. I mean, “the younger kind” was just a younger version of me. A senior likes a sophomore? How scandalous! Alas, a mature adult can’t abide a message like that. And the guilty pleasure of a rollicking song with a great beat is too guilty if you take it too seriously. Nowadays, if I hear the song come on at Trader Joe’s, I bop my head and pretend I’m playing bass, and I stop enjoying myself when the chorus gets to: “Never gonna stop giving up/Such a dirty mind.”

I've got a few favorite songs about how the world, or some aspect of it, is going downhill fast. I'm actually optimistic about the direction the world is heading (aside from climate change and the US moving toward a dictatorship). The most ironic example is “The Sound of Muzak” by Porcupine Tree. Released around 2002, it's about how music has lost its heart, it's just written by insincere millionaires looking to become billionaires, and it no longer has any meaningful content. It's a message I would have wholeheartedly embraced in the eighties (personal opinion, don't hate me), but by 2002 music was moving in a whole new direction. No thanks to the music industry and top forty radio, which were as bad as ever, but because independent artists and tiny labels could afford to produce their own music without worrying whether or not it was going to be a huge money-making hit. This very song is a prime example of what was finally going right on the music scene. I manage to enjoy the message of the song by imagining traveling back in time to the eighties and playing it then.
